channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Netanyahu Halts Some Settlement Plans, but Others to Proceed
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ’s move came after Secretary of State John Kerry criticized Israel’s continued construction in West Bank settlements.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: 2 Die in Blast at S. Africa Jewelry Pawn Shop
item.description: An explosion rocked a store that buys gold and jewelry in Johannesburg on Tuesday, killing at least two people and injuring three others. The exact cause of the blast was not immediately clear, but police did not suspect terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: How to Help Typhoon Victims in the Philippines
item.description: A list of contact information for some organizations that plan to provide relief to victims of Typhoon Haiyan.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 12
item.description: A drill performed by Indian Air Force Personnel in Goalpara, Assam.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Listening Post: After Near Miss on Iran, Kerry Says Diplomacy Is Still the Right Path
item.description: As the prospect of a nuclear deal with Iran becomes more real, Secretary of State John Kerry is having to fend off those who want to pre-empt it — like Israel and Iran hawks in Congress.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry last week in Geneva, where negotiations ended without a deal on Iran’s disputed nuclear program.

item.title: Economix Blog: The Inequality of Climate Change
item.description: The typhoon that ravaged the Philippines underscores what many development experts say is a cruel truth about climate change: It will hit the world’s poorest the hardest.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Changes in physical and biological systems and surface temperature, 1970-2004. Source: .

item.title: U.N. Appeals for $301 Million for Typhoon Response in the Philippines
item.description: The appeal for emergency assistance came a day after the top United Nations relief official flew to the Philippines to help lead the global response.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Anger Takes Hold in City Ravaged by Typhoon
item.description: The people of Tacloban, the hardest hit city, have been struggling largely on their own as they wait for relief operations to reach them.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan waited for a military plane at the airport in Tacloban.

item.title: India Ink: Robin Hood in Varanasi
item.description: An actor wears police uniform for a film in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, and finds the attitude of men change radically.
item.dc:creator: By TANNISHTHA CHATTERJEE
item.media:description: A boy jumping into Ganges River in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, on May 27.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Leaders Urge More Market Control of Economy
item.description: Chinese Communist Party leaders vowed on Tuesday to push through changes that will give market competition a “decisive role” in allocating resources, and announced the formation of a new committee to oversee national security.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Paramilitary police officers outside the Great Hall of the People on Tuesday, as the Communist Party Central Committee gathered for its Third Plenum.

item.title: The Lede: Messages to and From Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan
item.description: Journalists deliver messages from survivors to loved ones as people all over the world struggle to find out what happened to their friends and relatives.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:description: A television reporter in the Philippines collected messages on scraps of paper from survivors of Typhoon Haiyan to their loved ones.

item.title: Letter From Europe: 2 U.S. Allies Diverge on Spy Program
item.description: Germany is on one end of the spectrum of reactions to American spying in Europe; Britain is on the other.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: A stunt man parachuted from a helicopter dressed as James Bond during the opening ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games. Spies have long commanded a near-mythical respect in Britain.

item.title: Indonesia Makes Surprise Rate Increase
item.description: The central bank on Tuesday raised its benchmark rate by a quarter percentage point to help contain the country’s current account deficit.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: India Ink: Murder in Goa Shakes Tourist Paradise
item.description: A Nigerian man’s murder in Goa draws attention to the underbelly of the coastal paradise.
item.dc:creator: By SHARON FERNANDES
item.media:description: Police officers manning a street in Goa on Oct. 31 after the death of a Nigerian national triggered protests in the state.

item.title: Rising Despair as Officials Struggle to Get Aid to Victims
item.description: Philippine officials found themselves on the defensive Tuesday over the pace of relief efforts as the plight of survivors of Typhoon Haiyan became increasingly precarious.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Survivors of Typhoon Haiyan waited for a military plane at the airport in Tacloban.

item.title: Iranian Official Faults Kerry and France for Breakdown in Talks
item.description: In posts on Twitter, Iran’s foreign minister challenged American and French officials over the failure of nuclear talks in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Seeking Mao’s Matrimonial Blessing
item.description: Dozens of couples converged on Mao Zedong’s hometown to exchange wedding vows, weeks before the country will celebrate the 120th anniversary of his birth.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Couples head to Mao Zedong's birthplace for a "Collective Red Wedding."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Israel Increasingly Courting China as an Ally
item.description: Israeli officials hope to win China to their side in dealings with Iran, Syria and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reviews honor guards during a welcoming ceremony last May in Beijing.

item.title: The Lede: Aerial Views of Devastation in the Philippines
item.description: For the first time since Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines, aerial views are showing the extent of the damage in some parts of the country, cut off because of downed communication lines.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Mauritania Confronts Long Legacy of Slavery
item.description: Mauritania abolished slavery decades ago, but by some measures, it still has the highest prevalence of the practice in the world, and the government has created an agency to wipe out “vestiges” of the problem.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noura Mint Mourada, now 18, became a slave to a family in Boutilimit, Mauritania, at the age of 4.

item.title: News Analysis: Spying Scandal Alters U.S. Ties With Allies and Raises Talk of Policy Shift
item.description: Revelations about the N.S.A. surveillance efforts in Europe are resulting in unprecedented backlash, and some wonder if it is more important to collect data on allies or to be able to work with them.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Filipinos in U.S. Feel Helpless as They Try to Contact Kin
item.description: More than 300,000 Filipinos live in Southern California, and many were busy arranging relief aid as they waited for word from relatives in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By IAN LOVETT
item.media:description: Trinidad Limbaga, with her daughter Teri Red in Los Angeles, said she was unable to reach her sister in the Philippines.

item.title: Typhoon in Philippines Casts Long Shadow Over U.N. Talks on Climate Treaty
item.description: In Warsaw, United Nations delegates suggested that a warming planet had turned Typhoon Haiyan, considered one of the strongest storms to make landfall on record, into a lethal monster.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN and JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: U.N. Relief Official to Help Coordinate Aid Efforts
item.description: Valerie Amos sought to take charge of the relief efforts in the Philippines as governments mobilized to rush supplies to the victims of the storm.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Valerie Amos, the United Nations under secretary general for humanitarian affairs, was expected to arrive in the Philippines on Tuesday. She released $25 million from a special fund to help pay for immediate assistance.

item.title: Struggle for Survival in Philippine City Shattered by Typhoon
item.description: Destroyed buildings lined every road of Tacloban, the city hit hardest by the typhoon, and many streets were still so clogged with debris that they were barely discernible.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Uprooted coconut trees near Guiuan in the Philippines, which was devastated by Typhoon Haiyan’s winds and storm surge.
